bring.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to take something or someone with you to the place where you are now, or to the place you are talking about
bring.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: It was the first time Joey had ever brought a girl home.
They brought news of further fighting along the border.
Is it OK if I bring some friends to the party?
For some reason, Jesse had brought a tape recorder with him.
bring.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to get something for someone and take it to them
bring.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Can you bring me another beer?
Robert asked the waiter to bring him the check.
While she was in prison, friends used to bring her books.
He expects me to bring everything to him.
bring.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to make a particular situation exist, or cause a particular feeling
bring.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: efforts to bring peace to the region
The strikes are expected to bring chaos.
The senator’s speech brought an angry response from civil rights groups.
bring.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to cause someone or something to reach a particular state or condition
bring.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: It was the war that first brought him to power (=made him have power over a country).
So far the US has been unable to bring him to justice (=make him be punished for his actions).
Bring the sauce to the boil (=heat it until it boils).
The country had been brought to its knees (=caused to be in such a bad condition that it is almost impossible to continue).
The trial was swiftly brought to an end.
bring.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to make something move in a particular direction
bring.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Bring your arm up slowly until it’s level with your shoulder.
The storm brought the old oak tree crashing down.
bring.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: if something brings people to a place, it makes them go there
bring.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The discovery of gold brought thousands of people to the Transvaal.
What brings you here on a night like this?
bring.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to make something available for people to use, have, enjoy etc
bring.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: The expansion of state education brought new and wider opportunities for working class children.
The government is launching a new initiative to bring jobs to deprived areas.
It’s a good sign – let’s hope it will bring us some luck.
bring.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: if a period of time brings a particular event or situation, the event or situation happens during that time
bring.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: The 1930s brought unemployment and economic recession.
Who knows what the future will bring?
bring.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: used when saying that something is the next thing that you want to talk about
bring.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: This brings me to the main point of today’s meeting.
bring.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if a programme is brought to you by a particular television or radio company, they broadcast it or make it
bring.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: This programme is brought to you by the BBC.
something is brought to you by somebody
bring.translation[0].note_box[0].section: bring peace/war
The treaty brought peace to both England and France.
bring chaos
A bomb scare brought chaos to the town centre yesterday.
bring somebody pleasure/joy/pain/grief etc
The decision brought him great relief.
bring something to an end/halt
It is our responsibility to discuss how this conflict can be brought to an end.
bring something to a close
At last the meeting was brought to a close.
bring something to a conclusion
Juvenile cases need to be brought to a conclusion quickly.
bring somebody to power
The revolution brought to power a communist government.
bring somebody to justice
The authorities swore that the killers would be brought to justice.
bring somebody into contact with somebody/something
The people of the island were suddenly brought into contact with the outside world.
bring something/somebody to their knees
A severe drought brought the country to its knees.
bring.translation[0].note_box[1].section: to take something or someone to the place where you are now, or the place where you are going
Have you brought your ticket with you?
He asked his father if he could bring a friend to stay.
to move something to another place, or help someone go to another place
I took a book with me to read on the train.
He was taken to hospital by ambulance.
to go to another place and come back with something or someone
I went upstairs to get my jacket.
Joseph told me to fetch the doctor, so I ran to the village.
bring.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to organize a legal case against someone
bring.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: a string of lawsuits brought by jobseekers who think they’re the victims of discrimination
Company directors are meeting with law enforcement officials to determine whether to bring criminal charges.
